newsitem.title: FINLAND: POLL - FINNISH TENDER RATE SEEN UNCHANGED TO JUNE.
newsitem.headline: POLL - FINNISH TENDER RATE SEEN UNCHANGED TO JUNE.

text.p: The Bank of Finland's tender rate, its chief monetary policy tool, is expected to remain unchanged at 3.00 percent in the next three months, but some see a hike within one year, according to a Reuters poll.
All 22 respondents -- dealers, analysts and economists at banks and corporate treasury departments -- expected the central bank to keep the tender rate on hold at least until early June.
Looking one year ahead, the tender rate was expected to move higher with the median of forecasts at 3.25 percent in a 2.85-4.00 percent range. The mean was 3.32 percent.
Four banks expected the Bank of Finland to keep the tender rate unchanged at 3.00 percent, while one bank forecast a cut to 2.85 percent by early March 1998.
Seven respondents saw the tender rate rising by 50 basis points to 3.50 percent and two expected it to be raised to 4.00 percent.
The quarterly poll was conducted by telephone on February 27. The forecasts were collected on an anonymous basis.

Forecasts by Aktia Bank, Bank of America (London), Banque Indosuez (Stockholm), CD Derivatives Ltd., Davy Protos, Den Danske Bank (Copenhagen), Enso, Handelsbanken Markets Finland, Huhtamaki Finance, Interbank, IVO, Kemira, Kesko, Merita Bank, Neste, Nokia, OKOBANK, Postipankki, SE-Banken (Helsinki), SOK, Unibank (Copenhagen) and UPM-Kymmene.
